title: Edward G. Robinson
text:
Edward G. Robinson (born Emanuel Goldenberg; ; December 12, 1893January 26, 1973) was a <a href="Romanian%20American">Romanian-born American</a> actor of stage and screen during <a href="Classical%20Hollywood%20cinema">Hollywood's Golden Age</a>. He appeared in 30 Broadway plays and more than 100 films during a 50-year career and is best remembered for his tough-guy roles as gangsters in such films as "<a href="Little%20Caesar%20%28film%29">Little Caesar</a>" and "<a href="Key%20Largo%20%28film%29">Key Largo</a>".
During the 1930s and 1940s, he was an outspoken public critic of <a href="fascism">fascism</a> and <a href="Nazism">Nazism</a>, which were growing in strength in Europe in the years which led up to <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a>. His activism included contributing over $250,000 to more than 850 organizations which were involved in war relief, along with contributions to cultural, educational and religious groups. During the 1950s, he was called to testify in front of the <a href="House%20Un-American%20Activities%20Committee">House Un-American Activities Committee</a> during the <a href="Red%20Scare%23Second%20Red%20Scare%20.281947.E2.80.9357.29">Red Scare</a>, but he was cleared of any deliberate <a href="Communism">Communist</a> involvement when he claimed that he was "duped" by several people whom he named (including screenwriter <a href="Dalton%20Trumbo">Dalton Trumbo</a>, according to the official Congressional record, "Communist infiltration of the Hollywood motion-picture industry"). As a result of being investigated, he found himself on Hollywood’s graylist, people who were on the Hollywood blacklist maintained by the major studios, but could find work at minor film studios on what was called Poverty Row.
Robinson's roles included an <a href="insurance%20investigator">insurance investigator</a> in the <a href="film%20noir">film noir</a> "<a href="Double%20Indemnity">Double Indemnity</a>", <a href="Dathan">Dathan</a> (the adversary of <a href="Moses">Moses</a>) in "<a href="The%20Ten%20Commandments%20%281956%20film%29">The Ten Commandments</a>", and his final performance in the <a href="Science%20fiction">science-fiction</a> story "<a href="Soylent%20Green">Soylent Green</a>". Robinson received an <a href="Academy%20Honorary%20Award">Academy Honorary Award</a> for his work in the film industry, which was awarded two months after he died in 1973. He is ranked number 24 in the <a href="American%20Film%20Institute">American Film Institute</a>'s list of the 25 <a href="AFI%27s%20100%20Years...100%20Stars">greatest male stars of Classic American cinema</a>.
Early years and education.
Robinson's original name was Emanuel Goldenberg. He was born into a <a href="Yiddish">Yiddish</a>-speaking <a href="History%20of%20the%20Jews%20in%20Romania">Romanian Jewish</a> family in <a href="Bucharest">Bucharest</a>, the son of Sarah (née Guttman) and Morris Goldenberg, a builder.
After one of his brothers was attacked by an <a href="Antisemitism">anti-semitic</a> mob, the family decided to <a href="Emigration">emigrate</a> to the United States. Robinson arrived in <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a> on February 21, 1904. "At <a href="Ellis%20Island">Ellis Island</a> I was born again," he wrote. "Life for me began when I was 10 years old." He grew up on the <a href="Lower%20East%20Side">Lower East Side</a>, and had his <a href="Bar%20and%20Bat%20Mitzvah">Bar Mitzvah</a> at <a href="First%20Roumanian-American%20Congregation">First Roumanian-American Congregation</a>. He attended <a href="Townsend%20Harris%20High%20School">Townsend Harris High School</a> and then the <a href="City%20College%20of%20New%20York">City College of New York</a>, planning to become a criminal attorney. An interest in acting and performing in front of people led to him winning an <a href="American%20Academy%20of%20Dramatic%20Arts">American Academy of Dramatic Arts</a> <a href="scholarship">scholarship</a>, after which he changed his name to "Edward G. Robinson" (the G. standing for his original <a href="surname">surname</a>).
He served in the <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a> during <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, but was never sent overseas.
Career.
Theatre.
He began his acting career in the <a href="Yiddish%20Theatre%20District">Yiddish Theatre District</a> in 1913, he made his <a href="Broadway%20theatre">Broadway</a> debut in 1915. He made his film debut in "Arms and the Man" (1916).
In 1923, he made his named debut as "E.G. Robinson" in the silent film, "<a href="The%20Bright%20Shawl">The Bright Shawl</a>".
"The Racket".
He played a snarling gangster in the 1927 <a href="Broadway%20theatre">Broadway</a> police/crime drama "<a href="The%20Racket%20%281927%20play%29">The Racket</a>", which led to his being cast in similar film roles, beginning with "<a href="The%20Hole%20in%20the%20Wall%20%281929%20film%29">The Hole in the Wall</a>" (1929) with <a href="Claudette%20Colbert">Claudette Colbert</a> for <a href="Paramount%20Pictures">Paramount</a>.
One of many actors who saw their careers flourish in the new <a href="sound%20film">sound film</a> era rather than falter, he made only three films prior to 1930, but left his stage career that year and made 14 films between 1930 and 1932.
Robinson went to <a href="Universal%20Pictures">Universal</a> for "<a href="Night%20Ride%20%281930%20film%29">Night Ride</a>" (1930) and MGM for "<a href="A%20Lady%20to%20Love">A Lady to Love</a>" (1930) directed by <a href="Victor%20Sj%C3%B6str%C3%B6m">Victor Sjöström</a>. At Universal he was in "<a href="Outside%20the%20Law%20%281930%20film%29">Outside the Law</a>" and "<a href="East%20Is%20West">East Is West</a>" (both 1930), then he did "<a href="The%20Widow%20from%20Chicago">The Widow from Chicago</a>" (1931) at <a href="First%20National%20Pictures">First National</a>.
"Little Caesar".
Robinson was established as a film actor. What made him a star was an acclaimed performance as the gangster Caesar Enrico "Rico" Bandello in "<a href="Little%20Caesar%20%28film%29">Little Caesar</a>" (1931) at <a href="Warner%20Bros">Warner Bros</a>.
Robinson signed a long-term contract with Warners. They put him in another gangster film, "<a href="Smart%20Money%20%281931%20film%29">Smart Money</a>" (1931), his only movie with <a href="James%20Cagney">James Cagney</a>. He was reunited with <a href="Mervyn%20LeRoy">Mervyn LeRoy</a>, director of "Little Caesar", in "<a href="Five%20Star%20Final">Five Star Final</a>" (1931), playing a journalist, and played a Tong gangster in "<a href="The%20Hatchet%20Man">The Hatchet Man</a>" (1932).
Robinson made a third film with LeRoy, "<a href="Two%20Seconds">Two Seconds</a>" (1932) then did a melodrama directed by <a href="Howard%20Hawks">Howard Hawks</a>, "<a href="Tiger%20Shark%20%28film%29">Tiger Shark</a>" (1932).
Warners tried him in a biopic, "<a href="Silver%20Dollar%20%28film%29">Silver Dollar</a>" (1932), where Robinson played <a href="Horace%20Tabor">Horace Tabor</a>, a comedy, "<a href="The%20Little%20Giant%20%281933%20film%29">The Little Giant</a>" (1933) and a romance, "<a href="I%20Loved%20a%20Woman">I Loved a Woman</a>" (1933).
Robinson was then in "<a href="Dark%20Hazard">Dark Hazard</a>" (1934), and "<a href="The%20Man%20with%20Two%20Faces%20%281934%20film%29">The Man with Two Faces</a>" (1934).
He went to Columbia for "<a href="The%20Whole%20Town%27s%20Talking">The Whole Town's Talking</a>" (1935), a comedy directed by John Ford. <a href="Sam%20Goldwyn">Sam Goldwyn</a> borrowed him for "<a href="Barbary%20Coast%20%28film%29">Barbary Coast</a>" (1935), again directed by Hawks.
Back at Warners he did "<a href="Bullets%20or%20Ballots">Bullets or Ballots</a>" (1936) then he went to Britain for "<a href="Thunder%20in%20the%20City">Thunder in the City</a>" (1937). He made "<a href="Kid%20Galahad%20%281937%20film%29">Kid Galahad</a>" (1937) with <a href="Bette%20Davis">Bette Davis</a> and <a href="Humphrey%20Bogart">Humphrey Bogart</a>. MGM borrowed him for "<a href="The%20Last%20Gangster">The Last Gangster</a>" (1937) then he did a comedy "<a href="A%20Slight%20Case%20of%20Murder">A Slight Case of Murder</a>" (1938). Again with Bogart in a supporting role, he was in "<a href="The%20Amazing%20Dr.%20Clitterhouse">The Amazing Dr. Clitterhouse</a>" (1938) then he was borrowed by Columbia for "<a href="I%20Am%20the%20Law%20%281938%20film%29">I Am the Law</a>" (1938).
World War II.
At the time <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> broke out in Europe, he played an <a href="Federal%20Bureau%20of%20Investigation">FBI</a> agent in "<a href="Confessions%20of%20a%20Nazi%20Spy">Confessions of a Nazi Spy</a>" (1939), the first American film which portrayed <a href="Nazism">Nazism</a> as a threat to the United States.
He volunteered for military service in June 1942 but was disqualified due to his age which was 48, although he became an active and vocal critic of <a href="fascism">fascism</a> and Nazism during that period.
MGM borrowed him for "<a href="Blackmail%20%281939%20film%29">Blackmail</a>", (1939). Then to avoid being typecast he played the biomedical scientist and Nobel laureate <a href="Paul%20Ehrlich">Paul Ehrlich</a> in "<a href="Dr.%20Ehrlich%27s%20Magic%20Bullet">Dr. Ehrlich's Magic Bullet</a>" (1940) and played <a href="Paul%20Julius%20Reuter">Paul Julius Reuter</a> in "<a href="A%20Dispatch%20from%20Reuter%27s">A Dispatch from Reuter's</a>" (1940). Both films were biographies of prominent Jewish public figures. In between, he and Bogart starred in "<a href="Brother%20Orchid">Brother Orchid</a>" (1940).
Robinson was teamed up with <a href="John%20Garfield">John Garfield</a> in "<a href="The%20Sea%20Wolf%20%281941%20film%29">The Sea Wolf</a>" (1941) and <a href="George%20Raft">George Raft</a> in "<a href="Manpower%20%281941%20film%29">Manpower</a>" (1941). He went to MGM for "<a href="Unholy%20Partners">Unholy Partners</a>" (1942) and made a comedy "<a href="Larceny%2C%20Inc.">Larceny, Inc.</a>" (1942).
Post-Warners.
Robinson was one of several stars in "<a href="Tales%20of%20Manhattan">Tales of Manhattan</a>" (1942) and "<a href="Flesh%20and%20Fantasy">Flesh and Fantasy</a>" (1943).
He did war films: "<a href="Destroyer%20%281943%20film%29">Destroyer</a>" (1943) at <a href="Columbia%20Pictures">Columbia</a>, and "<a href="Tampico%20%28film%29">Tampico</a>" (1944) at <a href="20th%20Century%20Fox">Fox</a>. At Paramount he was in <a href="Billy%20Wilder">Billy Wilder</a>'s "<a href="Double%20Indemnity">Double Indemnity</a>" (1944) with <a href="Fred%20MacMurray">Fred MacMurray</a> and <a href="Barbara%20Stanwyck">Barbara Stanwyck</a> where his riveting soliloquy on insurance actuarial tables (written by <a href="Raymond%20Chandler">Raymond Chandler</a>) is considered a career showstopper, and at Columbia he was in "<a href="Mr.%20Winkle%20Goes%20to%20War">Mr. Winkle Goes to War</a>" (1944). He then performed with <a href="Joan%20Bennett">Joan Bennett</a> and <a href="Dan%20Duryea">Dan Duryea</a> in <a href="Fritz%20Lang">Fritz Lang</a>'s "<a href="The%20Woman%20in%20the%20Window%20%281944%20film%29">The Woman in the Window</a>" (1944) and "<a href="Scarlet%20Street">Scarlet Street</a>" (1945) where he played a criminal painter.
At MGM he was in "<a href="Our%20Vines%20Have%20Tender%20Grapes">Our Vines Have Tender Grapes</a>" (1945), and then <a href="Orson%20Welles">Orson Welles</a>' "<a href="The%20Stranger%20%281946%20film%29">The Stranger</a>" (1946), with Welles and <a href="Loretta%20Young">Loretta Young</a>. Robinson followed it with another thriller, "<a href="The%20Red%20House%20%28film%29">The Red House</a>" (1947), and starred in an adaptation of "<a href="All%20My%20Sons%20%28film%29">All My Sons</a>" (1948).
Robinson appeared for director <a href="John%20Huston">John Huston</a> as the gangster Johnny Rocco in "<a href="Key%20Largo%20%28film%29">Key Largo</a>" (1948), the last of five films which he made with <a href="Humphrey%20Bogart">Humphrey Bogart</a> and the only one in which Bogart did not play a supporting role.
He starred in "<a href="Night%20Has%20a%20Thousand%20Eyes">Night Has a Thousand Eyes</a>" in 1948 and starred in "<a href="House%20of%20Strangers">House of Strangers</a>" in 1949.
Greylisting.
Robinson found it hard to get work after his greylisting. He starred in low budget films: "<a href="Actors%20and%20Sin">Actors and Sin</a>" (1952), "<a href="Vice%20Squad%20%281953%20film%29">Vice Squad</a>" (1953) with brief appearances by second-billed <a href="Paulette%20Goddard">Paulette Goddard</a>, "<a href="Big%20Leaguer">Big Leaguer</a>" (1953) with <a href="Vera-Ellen">Vera-Ellen</a>, "<a href="The%20Glass%20Web">The Glass Web</a>" (1953) with <a href="John%20Forsythe">John Forsythe</a>, "<a href="Black%20Tuesday%20%28film%29">Black Tuesday</a>" (1954) with <a href="Peter%20Graves">Peter Graves</a>, "<a href="The%20Violent%20Men">The Violent Men</a>" (1955) with <a href="Glenn%20Ford">Glenn Ford</a> and <a href="Barbara%20Stanwyck">Barbara Stanwyck</a>, the well-received "<a href="Tight%20Spot">Tight Spot</a>" (1955) with <a href="Ginger%20Rogers">Ginger Rogers</a> and <a href="Brian%20Keith">Brian Keith</a>, "<a href="A%20Bullet%20for%20Joey">A Bullet for Joey</a>" (1955) with <a href="George%20Raft">George Raft</a>, "<a href="Illegal%20%281955%20film%29">Illegal</a>" (1955) with <a href="Nina%20Foch">Nina Foch</a>, and "<a href="Hell%20on%20Frisco%20Bay">Hell on Frisco Bay</a>" (1956) with <a href="Alan%20Ladd">Alan Ladd</a>.
His career's rehabilitation received a boost in 1954, when the noted <a href="Anti-communism">anti-communist</a> film director <a href="Cecil%20B.%20DeMille">Cecil B. DeMille</a> cast him as the traitorous <a href="Dathan">Dathan</a> in "<a href="The%20Ten%20Commandments%20%281956%20film%29">The Ten Commandments</a>". The film was released in 1956, as was his psychological thriller "<a href="Nightmare%20%281956%20film%29">Nightmare</a>".
After a subsequent short absence from the screen, Robinson's film career—augmented by an increasing number of television roles—restarted for good in 1958/59, when he was second-billed after Frank Sinatra in the 1959 release "<a href="A%20Hole%20in%20the%20Head">A Hole in the Head</a>".
Supporting actor.
Robinson went to Europe for "<a href="Seven%20Thieves">Seven Thieves</a>" (1960). He had support roles in "<a href="My%20Geisha">My Geisha</a>" (1962), "<a href="Two%20Weeks%20in%20Another%20Town">Two Weeks in Another Town</a>" (1962), "<a href="Sammy%20Going%20South">Sammy Going South</a>" (1963), "<a href="The%20Prize%20%281963%20film%29">The Prize</a>" (1963), "<a href="Robin%20and%20the%207%20Hoods">Robin and the 7 Hoods</a>" (1964), "<a href="Good%20Neighbor%20Sam">Good Neighbor Sam</a>" (1964), "<a href="Cheyenne%20Autumn">Cheyenne Autumn</a>" (1964), and "<a href="The%20Outrage">The Outrage</a>" (1964).
He was second-billed under <a href="Steve%20McQueen">Steve McQueen</a> with his name above the title in "<a href="The%20Cincinnati%20Kid">The Cincinnati Kid</a>" (1965; McQueen had idolized Robinson while growing up and opted for him when <a href="Spencer%20Tracy">Spencer Tracy</a> insisted on top billing for the same role), and was top billed in "<a href="The%20Blonde%20from%20Peking">The Blonde from Peking</a>". He also appeared in "<a href="Grand%20Slam%20%281967%20film%29">Grand Slam</a>" (1967) starring <a href="Janet%20Leigh">Janet Leigh</a> and <a href="Klaus%20Kinski">Klaus Kinski</a>.
Robinson was originally cast in the role of Dr. Zaius in "<a href="Planet%20of%20the%20Apes%20%281968%20film%29">Planet Of The Apes</a>" (1968) and he even went so far as to film a screen test with <a href="Charlton%20Heston">Charlton Heston</a>. However, Robinson dropped out of the project before its production began due to heart problems and concerns over the long hours which he would have needed to spend under the heavy ape makeup. He was replaced by <a href="Maurice%20Evans%20%28actor%29">Maurice Evans</a>.
His later appearances included "<a href="The%20Biggest%20Bundle%20of%20Them%20All">The Biggest Bundle of Them All</a>" (1968) starring <a href="Robert%20Wagner">Robert Wagner</a> and <a href="Raquel%20Welch">Raquel Welch</a>, "<a href="Never%20a%20Dull%20Moment%20%281968%20film%29">Never a Dull Moment</a>" (1968) with <a href="Dick%20Van%20Dyke">Dick Van Dyke</a>, "<a href="It%27s%20Your%20Move%20%281968%20film%29">It's Your Move</a>" (1968), "<a href="Mackenna%27s%20Gold">Mackenna's Gold</a>" (1969) starring <a href="Gregory%20Peck">Gregory Peck</a> and <a href="Omar%20Sharif">Omar Sharif</a>, and the "<a href="Night%20Gallery">Night Gallery</a>" episode “The Messiah on Mott Street" (1971).
The last scene which Robinson filmed was a <a href="euthanasia">euthanasia</a> sequence, with his friend and co-star <a href="Charlton%20Heston">Charlton Heston</a>, in the <a href="science%20fiction">science fiction</a> <a href="Cult%20following">cult film</a> "<a href="Soylent%20Green">Soylent Green</a>" (1973); he died only twelve days later.
Heston, as president of the <a href="Screen%20Actors%20Guild">Screen Actors Guild</a>, presented Robinson with its annual award in 1969, "in recognition of his pioneering work in organizing the union, his service during World War II, and his 'outstanding achievement in fostering the finest ideals of the acting profession.'"
Robinson was never nominated for an <a href="Academy%20Award">Academy Award</a>, but in 1973 he was awarded an <a href="Academy%20Honorary%20Award">honorary Oscar</a> in recognition that he had "achieved greatness as a player, a patron of the arts and a dedicated citizen ... in sum, a Renaissance man". He had been notified of the honor, but he died two months before the award ceremony took place, so the award was accepted by his widow, Jane Robinson.
Radio.
From 1937 to 1942, Robinson starred as Steve Wilson, editor of the "Illustrated Press", in the newspaper drama "<a href="Big%20Town">Big Town</a>". He also portrayed hardboiled detective <a href="Sam%20Spade">Sam Spade</a> for a <a href="Lux%20Radio%20Theatre">Lux Radio Theatre</a> adaptation of "<a href="The%20Maltese%20Falcon%20%28novel%29">The Maltese Falcon</a>". During the 1940s he also performed on CBS Radio's "Cadena de las Américas" network broadcasts to South America in collaboration with <a href="Nelson%20Rockefeller">Nelson Rockefeller</a>'s <a href="cultural%20diplomacy">cultural diplomacy</a> program at the U.S. State Department's <a href="Office%20of%20the%20Coordinator%20of%20Inter-American%20Affairs">Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs</a>.
Personal life.
Robinson was married twice, first to stage actress Gladys Lloyd, born Gladys Lloyd Cassell, in 1927; she was the former wife of Ralph L. Vestervelt and the daughter of Clement C. Cassell, an architect, sculptor and artist. The couple had one son, <a href="Edward%20G.%20Robinson%20Jr.">Edward G. Robinson, Jr.</a> (a.k.a. Manny Robinson, 1933–1974), as well as a daughter from Gladys Robinson's first marriage. In 1956 the couple divorced. In 1958 he married Jane Bodenheimer, a dress designer professionally known as Jane Arden. Thereafter he also maintained a home in <a href="Palm%20Springs%2C%20California">Palm Springs, California</a>.
In noticeable contrast to many of his onscreen characters, Robinson was a sensitive, soft-spoken and cultured man who spoke seven languages. Remaining a <a href="liberalism%20in%20the%20United%20States">liberal</a> <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democrat</a>, he attended the 1960 Democratic Convention in <a href="Los%20Angeles%2C%20California">Los Angeles, California</a>. He was a passionate art collector, eventually building up a significant private <a href="Collection%20%28museum%29">collection</a>. In 1956, however, he was forced to sell his collection to pay for his divorce settlement with Gladys Robinson; his finances had also suffered due to underemployment in the early 1950s.
Death.
Robinson died of <a href="bladder%20cancer">bladder cancer</a> at <a href="Cedars-Sinai%20Medical%20Center">Cedars Sinai Hospital in Los Angeles</a> on January 26, 1973. Services were held at Temple Israel in Los Angeles where <a href="Charlton%20Heston">Charlton Heston</a> delivered the eulogy. Over 1,500 friends of Robinson attended with another 500 crowded outside. His body was then flown to New York where it was entombed in a crypt in the family mausoleum at Beth-El Cemetery in Brooklyn. Among his pallbearers were <a href="Jack%20L.%20Warner">Jack L. Warner</a>, <a href="Hal%20B.%20Wallis">Hal B. Wallis</a>, <a href="Mervyn%20LeRoy">Mervyn LeRoy</a>, <a href="George%20Burns">George Burns</a>, <a href="Sam%20Jaffe">Sam Jaffe</a>, and <a href="Frank%20Sinatra">Frank Sinatra</a>.
In October 2000, Robinson's image was imprinted on a U.S. postage stamp, its sixth in its Legends of Hollywood series.
Political activism.
During the 1930s, Robinson was an outspoken public critic of <a href="fascism">fascism</a> and <a href="Nazism">Nazism</a>, and he also donated more than $250,000 to 850 political and charitable organizations between 1939 and 1949. He was host to the "Committee of 56" which gathered at his home on December 9, 1938, signing a "Declaration of Democratic Independence" which called for a boycott of all German-made products.
Although he attempted to enlist in the military at the outbreak of World War II, he was unable to do so because of his age; instead, the <a href="Office%20of%20War%20Information">Office of War Information</a> appointed him as a Special Representative based in London. From there, taking advantage of his multilingual skills, he delivered radio addresses in over six languages to European countries which had fallen under <a href="German-occupied%20Europe">Nazi domination</a>. His talent as a radio speaker in the U.S. had previously been recognized by the <a href="American%20Legion">American Legion</a>, which had given him an award for his "outstanding contribution to <a href="Americanism%20%28ideology%29">Americanism</a> through his stirring patriotic appeals". Robinson was also an active member of the Hollywood Democratic Committee, serving on its executive board in 1944, during which time he became an "enthusiastic" campaigner for Roosevelt's <a href="1944%20Democratic%20National%20Convention">reelection</a> that same year. During the 1940s Robinson also contributed to the <a href="cultural%20diplomacy">cultural diplomacy</a> initiatives of Roosevelt's <a href="Office%20of%20the%20Coordinator%20of%20Inter-American%20Affairs">Office of the Coordinator of Inter-American Affairs</a> in support of <a href="Pan-Americanism">Pan-Americanism</a> through his broadcasts to South America on the <a href="CBS">CBS</a> "Cadena da las Américas" radio network.
In early July 1944, less than a month after the <a href="Invasion%20of%20Normandy">Invasion of Normandy</a> by Allied forces, Robinson traveled to Normandy to entertain the troops, becoming the first movie star to go there for the <a href="USO">USO</a>. He personally donated $100,000 ($1,500,000 in 2015 dollars) to the USO. After returning to the U.S. he continued his active involvement in the war effort by going to shipyards and defense plants in order to inspire workers, in addition to appearing at rallies in order to help sell <a href="war%20bonds">war bonds</a>. After the <a href="Operation%20Barbarossa">Nazi invasion of the Soviet Union</a>, while he was not a supporter of <a href="Communism">Communism</a>, he appeared at Soviet war relief rallies in order to give moral aid to America's new ally, which he said could join "together in their hatred of Hitlerism".
After the war ended, Robinson publicly spoke out in support of <a href="Civil%20and%20political%20rights">democratic rights</a> for all Americans, especially in demanding equality for <a href="African%20Americans">Blacks</a> in the workplace. He endorsed the <a href="Fair%20Employment%20Practices%20Commission">Fair Employment Practices Commission</a>'s call to end workplace discrimination. Black leaders praised him as "one of the great friends of the Negro and a great advocator of Democracy". Robinson also campaigned for the civil rights of African-Americans, helping many people to overcome <a href="Racial%20segregation%20in%20the%20United%20States">segregation</a> and <a href="Racism%20in%20the%20United%20States">discrimination</a>.
During the years when Robinson spoke out against fascism and Nazism, he was not a supporter of Communism, but he did not criticize the <a href="Soviet%20Union">Soviet Union</a> which he saw as an ally against <a href="Adolf%20Hitler">Hitler</a>. However, notes the film historian Steven J. Ross, "activists who attacked Hitler without simultaneously attacking <a href="Joseph%20Stalin">Stalin</a> were vilified by <a href="Conservatism%20in%20the%20United%20States">conservative</a> critics as either Communists, Communist dupes, or, at best, as <a href="Naivety">naive</a> <a href="Liberalism%20in%20the%20United%20States">liberal</a> dupes." In addition, Robinson learned that 11 out of the more than 850 charities and groups which he had helped over the previous decade were listed as Communist front organizations by the FBI. As a result, he was called to testify in front of the <a href="House%20Un-American%20Activities%20Committee">House Un-American Activities Committee</a> (HUAC) in 1950 and 1952 and he was also threatened with <a href="Hollywood%20blacklist">blacklisting</a>.
As it appears in the full <a href="https%3A//archive.org/stream/communistinfiltr07unit/communistinfiltr07unit_djvu.txt">House Un-American Activities Committee transcript</a> for April 30, 1952, Robinson "<a href="informant">named names</a>" of Communist sympathizers (<a href="Albert%20Maltz">Albert Maltz</a>, <a href="Dalton%20Trumbo">Dalton Trumbo</a>, <a href="John%20Howard%20Lawson">John Howard Lawson</a>, <a href="Frank%20Tuttle">Frank Tuttle</a>, and <a href="Sidney%20Buchman">Sidney Buchman</a>) and repudiated some of the organizations which he had belonged to in the 1930s and 1940s. He came to realize, "I was duped and used." His own name was cleared, but in the aftermath, his career noticeably suffered, because he was offered smaller roles and they were offered to him less frequently. In October 1952, he wrote an article which was titled "How the Reds made a Sucker Out of Me", and it was published in the "American Legion Magazine." The chair of the committee, <a href="Francis%20E.%20Walter">Francis E. Walter</a>, told Robinson at the end of his testimonies, that the Committee "never had any evidence presented to indicate that you were anything more than a very choice sucker."
In popular culture.
Robinson has been the inspiration for a number of animated television characters, usually caricatures of his most distinctive 'snarling gangster' guise. An early version of the gangster character <a href="Rocky%20and%20Mugsy">Rocky</a>, featured in the <a href="Bugs%20Bunny">Bugs Bunny</a> cartoon "<a href="Racketeer%20Rabbit">Racketeer Rabbit</a>", shared his likeness. This version of the character also appears briefly in "<a href="Justice%20League%20%28TV%20series%29">Justice League</a>", in the episode "Comfort and Joy", as an alien with Robinson's face and non-human body, who hovers past the screen as a background character.
Similar caricatures also appeared in "<a href="The%20Coo-Coo%20Nut%20Grove">The Coo-Coo Nut Grove</a>", "<a href="Thugs%20with%20Dirty%20Mugs">Thugs with Dirty Mugs</a>" and "<a href="Hush%20My%20Mouse">Hush My Mouse</a>". Another character based on Robinson's tough-guy image was The Frog (Chauncey "Flat Face" Frog) from the cartoon series "<a href="Courageous%20Cat%20and%20Minute%20Mouse">Courageous Cat and Minute Mouse</a>". The voice of B.B. Eyes in "<a href="The%20Dick%20Tracy%20Show">The Dick Tracy Show</a>" was based on Robinson, with <a href="Mel%20Blanc">Mel Blanc</a> and <a href="Jerry%20Hausner">Jerry Hausner</a> sharing voicing duties. The "<a href="Wacky%20Races%20%281968%20TV%20series%29">Wacky Races</a>" animated series character 'Clyde' from the Ant Hill Mob was based on Robinson's Little Caesar persona.
Voice actor <a href="Hank%20Azaria">Hank Azaria</a> has noted that the voice of "<a href="The%20Simpsons">Simpsons</a>" character police chief <a href="Chief%20Wiggum">Clancy Wiggum</a> is an impression of Robinson. This has been explicitly joked about in episodes of the show. In "<a href="The%20Day%20the%20Violence%20Died">The Day the Violence Died</a>" (1996), a character states that Chief Wiggum is clearly based on Robinson. In 2008's "<a href="Treehouse%20of%20Horror%20XIX">Treehouse of Horror XIX</a>", Wiggum and Robinson's ghost each accuse the other of being rip-offs.
